DataElement.preferredName: DNA Assessment In Situ Hybridization Probe Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The name that describes the DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A deoxyribonucleotide polymer that is the primary genetic material of all cells. Eukaryotic and prokaryotic organisms normally contain DNA in a double-stranded state, yet several important biological processes transiently involve single-stranded regions. DNA, which consists of a polysugar-phosphate backbone possessing projections of purines (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidines (thymine and cytosine), forms a double helix that is held together by hydrogen bonds between these purines and pyrimidines (adenine to thymine and guanine to cytosine).

Concepts.definition: A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

ObjectClass.changeDescription: Changed long name ot EVS Preferred Name.  DW

Property.preferredDefinition: The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: Be specific about something; define clearly.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Tests, examinations, evaluations used to determine a subject's status or response to intervention.
ConceptualDomain.changeDescription: Created initially to support CCR value domain for CTMS.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues:General term for a piece of DNA or RNA corresponding to a gene or sequence of interest, that has been labelled either radioactively or with some other detectable molecule, such as biotin, digoxygenin or fluorescein. As stretches of DNA or RNA with complementary sequences will (hybridize), a probe will label viral plaques, bacterial colonies or bands on a gel that contain the gene of interest. (On-line Medical Dictionary):Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Use of a DNA or RNA probe to detect the presence of complementary sequences in chromosomes, cells, or tissues.

General term for a piece of DNA or RNA corresponding to a gene or sequence of interest, that has been labelled either radioactively or with some other detectable molecule, such as biotin, digoxygenin or fluorescein. As stretches of DNA or RNA with complementary sequences will hybridize, a probe will label viral plaques, bacterial colonies or bands on a gel that contain the gene of interest.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
